title: Am I allowed to contact the Trustee or Trustee's attorney in my Chapter 7 Bankruptcy case?
question: A motion to deny the homestead on my property was granted. My attorney was supposed to file an opposition to that motion and did not. He has admitted his mistake but now we have Realtors knocking on our door ready to sell our HOME. I firmly believe our homestead was wrongly denied and we have very solid evidence as to why is our home should be exempt. Since my attorney isn't very competent, I would like to talk the the trustee or trustee attorney myself. I am not sure if I need to hire a new attorney to try to fight for my home or if it is too late, since my current attorney dropped the ball big time. I am not sure if I should even worry about trying to save my house at this point or if I need to just hire an attorney to sue my current one for malpractice. Please advise. Thank you.
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Bankruptcy homestead exemption,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Appeals
answers: I am sure you can speak with the trustee's attorney. That attorney will not be able to advise you on any matters, and he or she cannot change the Court's ruling. You may be better off filing an appeal, or a motion for reconsideration based on your comments regarding your lawyer.

You filed a Chapter 7 Bankruptcy. Call the mortgage company and ask them to reaffirm the debt. If you are current on the mortgage payment then they should be able to reaffirm it. In Missouri, where I practice Bankruptcy Law, the mortgage company cannot foreclose on your home if you are current even after a Chapter 7 discharge and no reaffirmation agreement.

If you have an attorney, the trustee's attorney will not be able to speak to you due to ethical restrictions on communication with represented parties. There is nothing that would stop you from contacting the trustee directly. That being said, finding competent counsel who can zealously represent you should be priority number one to avoid losing your home!
Try talking to your present attorney to see if he can fix the issue.

i agree with another attorney response here that it is not possible to determine whether your current attorney "dropped the ball" as you say. if you are represented by counsel, the trustee's attorney is constrained by ethical duties not to speak to you directly. however, you may take the following courses of action:

1) contact the trustee (not its attorney) directly
2) contact your attorney and request written authorization for you to speak to the trustee's attorney directly. your attorney should advise you of the risks of taking this course of action. note you hired an attorney for a reason, which is to protect your interests. however, it's not unheard of that a client wants to have the option of making their own case.
3) do both 1 and 2

as another attorney colleague here suggested, you may wish to consult with another experienced bankruptcy attorney and get a second opinion on whether your home can be saved and in turn whether there may have possibly been malpractice. it's never too late to try or explore your options.

good luck to you.

please note further, this response is not intended to create an attorney-client relationship and should be used for informational purposes only.

Ask your attorney about a motion to set aside the under Rule 60 of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure. Also ask your attorney if you can file an amendment to still claim a homestead exemption.

For example, I am aware of a case where the debtor improperly claimed a $175,000 homestead exemption. The trustee filed an objection because the debtor was single wasn't entitled to that particularly exemption. However, there was a lower exemption that the debtor could claim and a simple amendment was in order to fix that issue.

It is impossible to know if your attorney did anything wrong from the facts presented in your question or if the situation can be fixed. it is always a good idea to consult with another local bankruptcy attorney and see if anything can be done in order to save your home. As long as your are represented by an attorney, you are not suppose to contact the trustee or the trustee's attorney since you are represented. They may refuse to talk with you. The contact need to be made through your counsel of record. Although you do have the right to terminate your current counsel if you wish to and then contact the trustee directly, I strongly advise you to use the services of a competent bankruptcy counsel. This does not seems to be a situation that pro-per persons can handle.
